awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Quantifying the relative importance of reproduction in forest dynamics under historical and future climate change
awd_abstract_narration:
Environmental change will alter forest dynamics and species composition. Tree reproduction and recruitment are critical processes for tree populations and ultimately, determine the future species composition of forests. Even though tree reproduction is sensitive to climate, the relative importance of this process for forest dynamics is unclear, especially compared to anticipated climate-change effects on tree growth and mortality. Seed production and seedling survival are also determined by individual and stand level properties. For example, seedling survival is affected by light availability. Increasing mortality due to climate change will alter the amount of light hitting the forest floor, and affect seedling survival. Seed production is also affected by size (i.e., larger individuals tend to produce more seed). If tree growth responds positively to climate change, this could indirectly cause an increase in seed production. Thus, to capture all these direct and indirect effects, the project will update a dynamic vegetation model (DVM) to explicitly simulate reproduction as a function of weather and stand structure. Including tree regeneration dynamics in process-based vegetation models is a major research gap and a critical step for accurately projecting forest responses to climate change. The project broader impacts include (1) training for students in computer programming, database management, data analysis, and communicating science, and (2) outreach activities to broaden participation of women in computer science.

Using forests located in the Pacific Northwest (PNW) as a case study, the project will quantify the relationships for seed production (as a function of weather and size) and seedling survival (as a function of weather and stand structure), for common tree species in the PNW. These relationships will be incorporated into a forest model, that already includes species-specific simulations of growth, competition and mortality as a function of the environment. The updated model will be used to simulate forest stands located in the PNW under historical climate and various climate change scenarios. By comparing model versions, the research will be able to quantify the relative role of reproduction on forest dynamics and species turnover and identify species vulnerable to climate change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Seed production and seedling survival are critical processes in forests. Both processes are also influenced by species-specific responses to weather and their environment, and it has been suggested that these regeneration processes will be affected by climate change. However, it is unknown what that would look like. Would all species experience similar increases or decreases in seed production? Would seed production responses differ from seedling survival? Would changes in seed production or seedling survival lead to changes in forest species composition and dynamics over longer time scales? 

To answer these questions, we used a forest gap model. These are process-based models that simulate the establishment, growth, competition and mortality of individual tree species. We were able to successfully update the forest model, so that we could simulate species-specific seed production as a function of weather and size, and simulate the transition from seedling to sapling, as a function of light availability and weather. We decided to focus on forests in the Pacific Northwest (PNW) due to the availability of data for parametrizing the model, and the large elevation gradient that produces a variety of different forest types in a relatively small area. We took advantage of the modelling approach, to create different scenarios where we turned on or off the different reproduction processes. For example, we created scenarios that did not include any of the updated regeneration processes, scenarios where seed production was always constant and the same for all species, scenarios where species-specific seed production was a function of weather, and so on. This allowed us to quantify the relative importance of the regeneration processes. We also simulated how forests would respond to different climate change scenarios, and if changes in regeneration could lead to changes in species composition. We found that the updated model (with species-specific regeneration processes) performed better than the original model without regeneration. Using the updated model, the simulated forests were more similar to observed forest data both in terms of above ground biomass, and species composition along the elevational gradient. We also found that seedling survival was more important for species diversity than seed production under historical climate conditions. Under climate change, the model projected large shifts in forest types. In particular, Douglas-fir increased in dominance under climate change, due to increases in seedling survival, establishment and growth. Other species, such as mountain hemlock and grand fir, were projected to experience significant declines in their dominance, in part due to reduced seedling survival and establishment rates. Overall, we found significant compositional changes in forests, due to climate change. We also found that species-specific regeneration processes played a pivotal role in determining which species thrive or decline in the future. The project funds also supported the development of a new coding workshop for middle school children, that uses robots to demonstrate block coding. This workshop is offered annually as part of the Ohio University TechSavvy event. This event brings both parents and students to campus and is designed to increase exposure to STEM careers, particularly for girls.
